prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation is about a couple where the husband set up his office in the bedroom instead of the basement, causing disruption to the wife's daily tasks and work.

First, I need to understand both sides. The husband chose the bedroom for better view, despite being offered the basement which is quieter. His job involves a lot of conference calls, so he needs silence. However, the wife is the one handling the kids and housework, and the setup in the bedroom is making it hard for her to do her job and take care of chores. She's also working from home and can't even take a shower without disturbing him. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom, so he's upset with her, but she thinks he's the one being unreasonable by not moving to the basement.

Is the author in the wrong? The key points here are about shared living space and mutual respect. The husband had the option to choose a better location for his work that would minimize disruption, but he chose not to. The wife is trying to manage both work and home responsibilities, and his choice is impacting her ability to do so. While it's true that the husband needs a quiet space to work, the fact that there's an available alternative (the basement) that he's ignoring seems to be a problem. The wife isn't being asked to make major sacrifices if he's in the basement, but by choosing the bedroom, he's limiting her space and increasing her workload. 

The husband's preference for the view is a personal choice that's affecting the household dynamics negatively. The wife's response was to set boundaries by offering the basement as a solution, which the husband rejected. So, the husband's decision is the root of the problem here. Therefore, the author (the wife) isn't in the wrong because she's trying to maintain balance and is within her rights to expect her living space not to be overly restricted. The answer should be B, she's not in the wrong.
